set off.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: I’ll set off early to avoid the traffic.
Jerry and I set off on foot for the beach.
set off.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to make something start happening, especially when you do not intend to do so
set off.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: News that the claims might be true set off widespread panic.
Hong Kong’s stock market fell, setting off a global financial crisis.
set off.translation[0].definitions[1].no: In written English, people often say that something triggers a particular reaction or event, rather than sets it off, because it sounds more formal:
This could trigger a global financial crisis.
set off.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to make an alarm start ringing
set off.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: Smoke from a cigarette will not normally set off a smoke alarm.
set off.translation[0].definitions[3].de: to make a bomb explode, or cause an explosion
set off.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: Any movement could have set off the bomb.
set off.translation[0].definitions[4].de: if a piece of clothing, colour, decoration etc sets something off, it makes it look attractive
set off.translation[0].definitions[4].ex: The blue sundress set off her long blonde hair.
set off.translation[0].definitions[5].de: to make someone start laughing, crying, or talking about something
set off.translation[0].definitions[5].ex: Don’t mention what happened – you’ll only set her off again.
set off.translation[0].definitions[6].de: to officially record the money you have spent on something connected with your job, in order to reduce the amount of tax you have to pay
set off.translation[0].definitions[6].ex: Some expenses can be set off against tax.
